text: {{Infobox scientist | name = Amartya Sen | native_name = অমর্ত্য সেন | native_name_lang = bn | image = Amartya Sen 2012.jpg | caption = Sen in 2012 | birth_date = | birth_place = Shantiniketan, then-British India | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Indian | spouse = Nabaneeta Dev (1958–1976) Eva Colorni (1978–1985) Emma Rothschild (m. 1991) | children =Nandana Sen | alma_mater = Presidency College of the University of Calcutta (BA), Trinity College, Cambridge (BA, MA, PhD) | field = Welfare economics, development economics, ethics | influences = | influenced = | awards = Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences (1998) Bharat Ratna (1999) National Humanities Medal (2012) | signature = }} Amartya Kumar Sen (born November 3, 1933) is an Indian economist. Since 1956, he has taught and worked in the United Kingdom and the United States. He worked in welfare economics, social choice theory, economic and social justice, economic theories of famines, and indexes of the measure of well-being of citizens of developing countries. He was awarded the Nobel Prize in Economics in 1998 and Bharat Ratna in 1999 for his work in welfare economics. He was also awarded the inaugural Charleston-EFG John Maynard Keynes Prize in recognition of his work on welfare economics in February 2015 during a reception at the Royal Academy in the UK. ==References== ==Further reading== * * ==Other websites== * Amartya Sen at Harvard University * The Possibility of Social Choice 1998 lecture at NobelPrize.org * Profile and Papers at Research Papers in Economics/RePEc * Category:1933 births Category:2021 deaths Category:Indian economists Category:American philosophers Category:American economists Category:British economists Category:British philosophers Category:Scientists from New York (state) Category:Indian Nobel Prize winners Category:Ambedkarites
